Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I stood at the corner, sweat trickling down my back in the heavy heat. My stepbrother, always impatient, darted toward the crosswalk, barely glancing at the traffic. My heart leapt—my mom’s words echoed in my mind: “Look out for each other.” I was supposed to keep him safe, to make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But just as I reached out to call him back, I remembered Mrs. Patel, our elderly neighbor. The city had issued a heat advisory, and she lived alone on our floor. The community center had asked us to check on vulnerable neighbors, to make sure they had water and their fans were working. I felt torn—if I chased after my stepbrother, I might miss the chance to help Mrs. Patel before the worst of the heat set in. But if I left him, what if he stepped into traffic? My chest tightened as I tried to weigh the demands: family or community, immediate danger or silent suffering. I hesitated, caught between the two worlds, unsure which way to turn.
